sentence: That bill didn’t get any Democratic backing on the committee but had support from an unlikely source, former Maricopa County Recorder Adrian Fontes.
author: Jeremy Duda
title: Lies about the 2020 election propel Arizona bills aimed at combating non-existent fraud

sentence: In 2018, then-Maricopa County Recorder Adrian Fontes made it easier for such people to vote, opening emergency voting centers in Mesa, Scottsdale, Avondale and Tolleson, in addition to the usual emergency voting site at the Maricopa County Recorder’s Office in downtown Phoenix.
author: Laurie Roberts
title: The Easier to Vote, Harder to Cheat Act? Anonymous Republicans think we'd fall for that?

sentence: Democratic County Recorder Adrian Fontes led Republican challenger Stephen Richer for four days, falling behind over the weekend after the election, one of several countywide Democratic candidates who saw their leads evaporate in the days after the election.
author: Jeremy Duda
title: GOP ballot measure in Arizona would restrict early voting to speed up ballot counting

sentence: Latino Victory recently endorsed Arizona gubernatorial candidate Marco Lopez, and has done the same with other prominent Arizona politicians such as Adrian Fontes and Daniel Hernandez.
author: Javier Arce
title: 'A slap in the face to the voters': Voto Latino launches campaign to replace Sen. Kyrsten Sinema

sentence: He told voters that former Maricopa County Recorder Adrian Fontes is a “criminal.” One year before his election, Richer wrote, This confidence has been further damaged by the fact that Fontes has not given a full accounting for his actions in the election, and his Office has failed to produce documents in response to the multiple records requests put forward by the Republican and its surrogate (me).
author: Jordan Conradson
title: EXCLUSIVE: Leaked Emails From Maricopa County Recorder Stephen Richer Reveal Voter Fraud Concerns Before 2020 Election

sentence: Abraham Hamadeh, a Republican candidate in Arizona’s attorney general election, attacked the former recorder in the state’s most populous county (Adrian Fontes, a Democrat now running for secretary of state in Arizona) for unspecified “unconstitutional” actions “to hijack our elections.” Ashley Moody, the Republican incumbent in Florida’s attorney general race, urged the U.S. Supreme Court to hear a motion from Texas’ attorney general seeking to overturn the Electoral College results from other battleground states, saying “the process” was not followed, but not citing evidence.
title: More than 80 election-denying candidates running for governor, attorney general and secretary of state in 2022’s primaries

sentence: Abraham Hamadeh, a Republican candidate in Arizona’s attorney general election, attacked the former recorder in the state’s most populous county (Adrian Fontes, a Democrat now running for secretary of state in Arizona) for unspecified “unconstitutional” actions “to hijack our elections.” Ashley Moody, the Republican incumbent in Florida’s attorney general race, urged the U.S. Supreme Court to hear a motion from Texas’ attorney general seeking to overturn the Electoral College results from other battleground states, saying “the process” was not followed, but not citing evidence.
author: Chris Walker
title: More Than 80 Candidates in 2022 Primaries Are Spreading Trump’s “Big Lie”
